Description: Shoulder sherd (slight ridge at top of fragment) of Ionian pottery dinos; buff slip; exterior: part of two male figures to left; the one on the left plays a double flute; he has long hair and wears an elaborate phorbeia (cheek-band) and a chiton with spotted border; only shoulder area of figure on right preserved.
Excavator/field collector: Excavated by: Dr David George Hogarth
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Ashmolean Museum, Oxford. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

Possibly joins (certainly from same pot as) British Museum 1888,0601.780 (Cook 1933-1934, 53, pl. 10b). According to Cook (1933-1934, 53) the sherd does not belong to a Fikellura vase, but possibly to a poor example of Chian pottery.
Bibliographic references: Lemos 1991 / Archaic Pottery of Chios. The Decorated Styles (p. 284, no. 805, pl. 112)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GG.437)
Previous owner: Currently owned by: Ashmolean Museum, University of Oxford
